title: Suzanne Simard: Mother Trees and the Social Forest - The Long Now

last_post.content:
Suzanne Simard has started a 100-year project to help the social forest (aka "tree neighborhoods") migrate north -- across the clear-cut landscape we've created -- so it can flourish in the subarctic as things warm up and provide ecosystem services including carbon sequestration, water capture, and fire resilience.

Don't miss the part about bears, and then native people, depositing salmon carcasses at the base of mother trees to feed the forest. ❤️

https://longnow.org/seminars/02021/jun/15/mother-trees-and-social-forest/

We looked at the impact of surfacing moral framing in online discussions about news on contentious topics, finding in a small scale study that it helped people consider how to frame their own arguments in the moral values of the opposing side.

title: Notes from a data witch - Everything I know about Mastodon

last_post.content:
@NicoleCRust field-specific hashtags for paper announcements and threads might not work so well for those of us with poor memories and interests across multiple fields, because we would have to remember the specific hashtags for each field.

The Mastodon advanced web interface allows you to follow combinations of hashtags (instructions here: https://blog.djnavarro.net/posts/2022-11-03_what-i-know-about-mastodon/#tracking-hashtags) but it doesn't appear to allow for (#neuroscience AND (#NewPaper OR #PaperThread)), plus I think I found a bug.

For now, I think I will follow (#PaperThread OR #NewPaper OR #NeuroPaperThread OR #NeuroNewPaper OR ...).

Plus, I'm copying in @cogsci #CogSci and #CompCogSci because this is an issue that needs to be discussed in all research communities.

@aparrish We see related problems in clinical #neurology, where our diagnostic criteria for aphasia assume English structure. E.g., one diagnostic criterion for semantic dementia is "surface dysgraphia"--improper regularization, like writing "yacht" as "yot." But this criterion relies on English's orthographic opacity, and wouldn't appear in languages like Spanish, Korean or Russian with more regular orthography.

Here's a fascinating paper by my colleague Boon Lead Tee on dysgraphia in Chinese-speakers with primary progressive aphasia: https://doi.org/10.1212/wnl.0000000000200350. Because Chinese writing is so different from English, these disorders manifest in really interestingly different ways--some analogous to presentations in English, others entirely distinct. Anyway, a challenge for cross-cultural diagnosis and management...

Perfectly targeted advertising is just information.

These surprising facts are explained in detail here:

• Byron Schmuland, Random harmonic series, Amer. Math. Monthly 110 (2003), 407–416. http://www.stat.ualberta.ca/people/schmu/preprints/rhs.pdf

Other nice facts: the random harmonic series

± 1 ± ½ ± ⅓  ± ¼ ± ⅕ ± ⅙ ± ...

converges with probability 1. Its variance is π²/6. (This is easy enough that you might be able to show it yourself!) And the probability that it exceeds some number x ≥ 0 is

≤ exp(−3𝑥²/π²)

so it's rarely very big.

(3/n, n = 3)

title: Fedfree – Update to Debian Nginx guide

last_post.content:
Update to the Nginx web server guide on Fedfree:

https://fedfree.org/news/debian-nginx-update.html

If you followed the tutorial before, it would have told you for LetsEncrypt challenge responses (creation/renewal/revocation), that you had to *stop* nginx. A follow-up guide, briefly online but now deleted, had you temporarily disable HTTP-to-HTTPS redirects.

The main guide is now updated and says how to renew/create/revoke certificates *without disabling anything*.

Everything now stays online. Nothing goes down, ever.

title: Language models can only write poetry

somehow missed this excellent essay by @aparrish on why language models can *only* write poetry

dovetails really well with my recent thinking about simulation (esp social sim) as a medium & why it feels to me less narrative than poetic somehow. the sim outputs we most value are the ones where the machine accidentally says more than it knows how to intend – where it's *trying* to enframe a story in terms it understands but something important *escapes* its understanding
